newsitem.title: ISRAEL: Israeli defence firms won $2 bln in orders in 1996.
newsitem.headline: Israeli defence firms won $2 bln in orders in 1996.

text.p: A top Israeli official said on Monday that state-owned defence companies had signed export contracts last year worth more than two billion dollars, up 25 percent over 1995.
Defence Ministry director-general Ilan Biran said he hoped the companies, burdened by years of heavy losses, would turn a profit equal to three percent of turnover next year.
"In 1996 we reached signed contracts worth slightly more than two billion dollars," Biran told reporters in Tel Aviv, adding that some of the contracts were multi-year deals.
Israel's Treasury has spent more than a billion dollars in recent years bailing out state-owned defence firms which have been buffeted by declining domestic orders and stiff competition abroad.
Israel Aircraft Industries (IAI), the largest of the state-owned defence companies, lost $40 million in 1996 but management projects earnings of $22 million on $1.62 billion in sales this year.

Biran said he hoped Israel would begin privatising IAI next year after the expiry on December 31 of a collective agreement that gives workers the right to veto any sell-off. IAI's powerful trade union has opposed privatisation efforts.
"For this reason we're talking about (launching privatisation in) 1998 and I hope it will materialise," Biran told reporters.
Prime Minister Benjamin has vowed to privatise 50 state-owned companies during his term but officials have said the defence firms would be left for last.
Some analysts have said obstacles to privatising the country's defence firms, including union opposition and political considerations, are too formidable for the government to surmount.
